snippet: Jelani Thomas is entering the work force with a brand-new bachelor’s degree and plenty of hope. The sluggish economic recovery, however, is making it hard for him to see his next move.
abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column examines plight of Jelani Thomas, child of Trinidadian immigrants who now holds heard-earned bachelor's degree in business management and finance from Brooklyn College; notes Thomas and fellow Brooklyn College graduates face labor market in New York City that continues to be weak in face of a decade of economic upheaval, with tough battle ahead to find full-time work in their fields.
lead_paragraph: Jelani Thomas is entering the work force with a brand-new bachelor’s degree and plenty of hope. The sluggish economic recovery, however, is making it hard for him to see his next move.

headline.seo: Brooklyn College Graduates Step In to Depressing Job Market
headline.main: Degree? Check. Enthusiasm? Check. Job? Not So Fast.
headline.print_headline: Degree? Check. Enthusiasm? Check. Job? Not So Fast.

keywords.value: Brooklyn College, City University of New York
keywords.name: organizations
